title: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India (2017)
text: A nine-judge bench recognized the Right to Privacy as a fundamental right under Article 21. Any restriction must satisfy legality (backed by law), legitimate aim, necessity and proportionality, and procedural safeguards. Aadhaar-context dicta emphasized minimal intrusion and data protection norms.

title: Modern Dental College v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2016)
text: Adopted structured proportionality: legitimate goal, suitability, necessity (least restrictive means), and balancing. Used as a reference framework in later fundamental rights cases.

title: Aadhaar (2018) Partial Upholding with Safeguards
text: Upheld core Aadhaar for targeted benefits with safeguards, struck down overly broad uses. Reiterated privacy limits: purpose limitation, data minimization, oversight, and security controls.

title: Data Protection & Procedural Safeguards (General Principles)
text: Key safeguards: clear purpose limitation, storage limitation, independent oversight, user rights, audit trails, breach notification, and proportional penalties. Biometric handling demands high necessity.

title: Hypothetical: Biometric Mandates in Non-essential Services
text: Where non-essential services are involved, blanket biometric mandates often fail necessity if alternatives (smartcards, OTP, in-person verification) can mitigate fraud comparably with less intrusion.
